entry.title: Fair Division 8 Strategic Aspects of Fair Divison
entry.content:
Objective: Investigate strategic aspects of fair division, considering Pure Nash equilibria and fairness.

Activities: Review the paper Allocating Indivisible Goods to Strategic Agents: Pure Nash Equilibria and Fairness.

Abstract

What if the agents are strategic?

Goal: whether there exist mechanisms that have pure Nash Equilibria. If so, what is the fairness guarantee for these equilibria?

Focus on EF1, EFX. The answer is positive.

2 algorithms:

  • round-robin (computing EF1 allocation). Its pure Nash equilibria are EF1 w.r.t. true values.
  • cut and choose algorithm (computing EFX allocation for 2 agents). The corresponding allocations not only are EFX, but also satisfy MMS. A weaker result holds for any mechanism for two agents that always has pure Nash equilibria, which all induce EFX allocations.

Introduction

This paper is interested in exploring the problem from a game-theoretic perspective.

Assume that the agents are strategic, i.e., agent may misreport its true valuation for the goods to end up with a bundle of higher total value.

The algorithm takes the input values (which are probably misreported) the agents declare.

The existence of truthful mechanisms. Even for 2 agents, truthfulness and fairness are incompatible by providing impossibility results for every non-trivial fairness notion. So next natural question: Is it possible to have non-truthful mechanisms that are guaranteed to have equilibria with these equilibria always inducing fair allocations?

Contributions

The class of mechanisms that are implementable in polynomial time have pure Nash equilibria for every instance and provide some fairness guarantee as the allocations they produce in their equilibria is non-empty.

  • Round-robin has pure Nash equilibria for every instance, and these equilibria induce allocations that are known properties of round-robin with a novel recursive construction of “nicely structured” bid profiles.
  • Mod-Cut&Choose has pure Nash equilibria for every instance with 2 agents, and these equilibria induce allocations that are always EFX and MMS w.r.t. the underlying true values. For the case of 2 agents, MMS allocations are always EFX allocations; i.e., MMS fairness is stronger. In non-strategic setting, for any ϵ>0\epsilon\gt 0ϵ>0, there are instances in which the output of Mod-Cut&Choose is not (5/6+ϵ)(5/6+\epsilon)(5/6+ϵ)-MMS allocation.
  • A weaker result. All mechanisms that have pure Nash equilibria for every instance with 2 agents and these equilibria induce allocations that are always EFX provide stronger MMS guarantees in these allocations than generic EFX allocations do.

Related Works

Omitted

Preliminaries

Goods MMM, agents NNN.

Valuations v\mathbf vv are additive, non-negative.

All the goods must be allocated.

Allocation AAA.

Preference ≽i,≻i\succcurlyeq_i,\succ_i≽i​,≻i​

Fairness Notions

EF, EF1, EFX

PROP

MMS, α\alphaα-MMS

🎯🤔Theorem 1. For n=2n=2n=2, any MMS allocation is also an EFX allocation.

For n=2n=2n=2, MMS allocation is indeed PMMS allocation. Any PMMS allocation is EFX allocation.

🎯🤔Theorem 2. For n=2n=2n=2, any EFX is also 2/32/32/3-MMS allocation. The bound is tight for any m≥4m\ge4m≥4.

Mechanisms and Equilibria

An allocation mechanism M\mathcal MM is an algorithm that takes its input from the agents and allocates all the goods to them.

Assume each agent iii reports a bid vector bib_ibi​, where bij≥0b_{ij}\ge0bij​≥0 is the value agent iii claims to have for good gjg_jgj​. M\mathcal MM takes bid profile b\mathbf bb of bid vectors and outputs an allocation M(b)\mathcal M(\mathbf b)M(b).

Assume that the agents are strategic (They may misreport their true values in order to get a bundle with higher value).

Hence, in general, bi≠(vi(g1),⋯ ,vi(gm))\mathbf b_i\neq(v_i(g_1),\cdots,v_i(g_m))bi​=(vi​(g1​),⋯,vi​(gm​)).

Focus: Fairness guarantees of the pure Nash equilibria of the mechanisms.

Best response.

The profile b\mathbf bb is pure Nash equilibria (PNE) if for each i∈Ni\in Ni∈N, bi\mathbf b_ibi​ is a best response to b−i\mathbf b_{-i}b−i​.

When b\mathbf bb is a PNE and the allocation M(b)\mathcal M(\mathbf b)M(b) has a fairness guarantee, we say that b\mathbf bb is EF1.

Some remarks:

  1. Here we don’t consider too much about the complexity of mechanism.
  2. Any PNE of any α\alphaα-approximation mechanism for computing MMS allocation is an α\alphaα-MMS allocation. This is also true for PROP.

Fairness of Nash Equilibria of Round-Robin

Round-Robin Mechanism takes a bid profile as input. Then RR should also take a permutation NNN as an input to determine the priority of the agents.

WLOG, let the permutation be 1,2,⋯ ,n1,2,\cdots,n1,2,⋯,n.

It’s known that RR outputs EF1 allocation when all agents have additive valuation functions.

Pseudo-code: Omitted, can refer to here.

🤔Lemma 1. If bi\mathbf b_ibi​ is the truthful bid of agent iii, then the allocation A\mathcal AA returned by Round-Robin is EF1 from iii’s perspective. Moreover, if i=1i=1i=1, then A\mathcal AA is EF from agent 111’s perspective, i.e., ∀j∈N,v1(A1)≥v1(Aj)\forall j\in N,v_1(A_1)\ge v_1(A_j)∀j∈N,v1​(A1​)≥v1​(Aj​).

Truth-telling is not a Pure Nash equilibria. Example omitted.

RR is known to have PNE for any instance in which no agent values two goods exactly the same and at least some such equilibria are easy to compute. Strict preference ranking is convenient as it reduces the number of corner case with which one has to deal. This results can be extended to general additive valuation functions.

For only 2 agents, all PNE of round-robin are EF1 w.r.t. the real valuation functions. Complex even for n=3n=3n=3.

Nash Equilibria of Round-Robin for Any Number of Agents

Agent 1 have no envy toward any other bundle whenever agent 1 bids truthfully. Agent 1 is EF-satisfied.

No matter what agent 1 bids, it is possible to “replace” the agent with an imaginary version of agent, who

  1. does not affect the allocation
  2. bids truthfully
  3. considers the bundles of the allocation to be as valuable as the original agent 1 though they were

EFX Equilibria: The Case of 2 Agents

When the agents are not strategic, EFX exist when n≤3n\le3n≤3.

Even for n=3n=3n=3, we are not sure whether there is a polynomial time algorithm.

We consider n=2n=2n=2 in this paper.

Mechanism with EFX Nash Equilibria

A polynomial time algorithm that outputs EFX allocation when we have 2 agents: modified cut-and-choose algorithm in which cut is a variant of envy-cycle-elimination. In this paper, we refer it as “Mod-Cut&Choose”.

This mechanism is not truthful.

This paper shows that although its non-truthful, Mod-Cut&Choose always has at least one PNE for any instance, and all its equilibria are MMS and EFX. (MMS for 2 agent is PMMS, PMMS is EFX.)

So agent 111 forces the partition that maximizes (according v1v_1v1​) the value of the least desirable bundle according to v2v_2v2​.

Now it’s easy to see that given the bidding strategy of agent 222 (truth-telling), there is no deviation for agent 111 that is profitable. Moreover, agent 222 gets the best of the two bundles according to the agent’s valuation function (truth-telling is dominant strategy for agent 222). Thus, there is no profitable deviation for the agent either. Therefore (b1,b2)(\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_2)(b1​,b2​) is a PNE for I\mathcal II.

Suppose a contradiction that there is a PNE b\mathbf bb, for which an agent iii does not achieve the agent’s μi\mu_iμi​ in the allocation returned by Mod-Cut&Choose(b\mathbf bb). If it’s agent 111, then according to Corollary 111, there is a bid vector b1′\mathbf b_1'b1′​ the agent can report so that the algorithm produces a μ1\mu_1μ1​-partition. By deviating to b1′\mathbf b_1'b1′​, regardless of the set given to agent 222, agent 111 ends up with a bundle the agent values at least μ1\mu_1μ1​. This would be a strict improvement over the agent’s current gain, contradicting that b\mathbf bb is PNE.

So it must be the case that agent 222 gets a bundle that strictly less than μ2\mu_2μ2​. Regardless of the partition, by declaring the truthful bid, agent 222 gets a bundle of value at least v2(M)/2v_2(M)/2v2​(M)/2. Then it’s immediate to see that this value is at least μ2\mu_2μ2​, which is a contradiction.

So it’s MMS for 222 agents, thus it’s PMMS, thus EFX.

The Enhanced Fairness of EFX Nash Equilibria

Consider the class of mechanisms that have PNE for every instance, and these equilibria always lead to EFX allocations.

Goal: If these allocations have better fairness guarantees than EFX allocation in general.

2 agents + 4 goods, this paper proved that for every mechanism of this class, all allocations at a PNE are MMS allocations. By Theorem 2, there are instances with just 4 goods in which an EFX allocation is 2/32/32/3-MMS (tight bound).

🤔Lemma 5. Consider an instance with 222 agents and 444 goods. If agent i∈[2]i\in[2]i∈[2] has strictly positive value for 333 or fewer goods, then in every allocation that is EFX from the agent’s point of view, agent iii has value at least μi\mu_iμi​.

Suppose agent iii has positive value for at most 3 goods. The statement is trivial when there is at most one positively valued good as in this case μi=0\mu_i=0μi​=0, and agent iii always gets μi\mu_iμi​ no matter the bundle that agent gets. When agent has a positive value for two goods, in order to consider the allocation as EFX, the agent must get at least one of them. In this case, the agent also achieves the agent’s μi\mu_iμi​ as it is equal to the smaller of the 2 positive values.

Suppose agent iii has positive value for 3 goods, notice that μi\mu_iμi​ in this case is equal to min⁡(\min(min(the largest one, the sum of two smallest values))). If agent iii gets 2 goods, then the agent always derives a value of at least μi\mu_iμi​. If agent gets just one good, then this good must have the highest value; otherwise the agent wouldn’t consider the allocation as EFX. So agent gets value at least μi\mu_iμi​.

Thus v1(A2)≥4μi/3v_1(A_2)\ge4\mu_i/3v1​(A2​)≥4μi​/3 because v1(M)≥2μ1v_1(M)\ge2\mu_1v1​(M)≥2μ1​ by definition of MMS.

Finally, let x∈arg⁡min⁡g∈Sv1(g)x\in\arg\min_{g\in S}v_1(g)x∈argming∈S​v1​(g) be a minimum valued good for agent 111 in SSS. We have

where the first inequality follows from EFX. Observe that k≤2k\le2k≤2, this implies k=2k=2k=2.

Discussion

This paper discusses fair division with indivisible goods to a set of strategic agents.

Surprisingly, there exists strong impossibilities for truthful mechanisms. The paper shows that there exist mechanisms that have PNE for every instance, and at the same time the PNE allocation have strong guarantees w.r.t. true valuations.

Possible directions for future work:

  • Algorithm that compute EF1 allocations for richer valuation function domains (Envy-cycle elimination) in strategic setting.

    • Does there exist pure or mixed Nash Equilibria?
    • If there exist NE, does it still maintain fairness properties at the NE?

  • Theorem 7&8 leave an open problem: MMS guarantee that the equilibria of mechanisms that always have PNE and these are EFX.

    • suspect: corresponding allocations are not always MMS.
    • For every such mechanism that runs in polynomial time, finding a best response of an agent is NP. For n≥3n\ge3n≥3 the problem is absolutely non-trivial.

  • The complexity for computing best response. Want to know if best response dynamics always converge to a PNE or there might be cyclic behavior?

entry.title: 西语学习 A1 Unidad 2 ¿Cómo estás?
entry.content:
Vocabulario

副词

muy adv. 很

动词

estar intr. 在；处于

estar 的变位：estoy - estás - está - estamos - estáis - están

物主形容词（非重读，放在名词的前面）

⚠️物主形容词修饰复数名词时，词尾加 s

我的 mi

你的 tu

TA的、您的 su

我们的 nuestro, nuestra

你们的 vuestro, vuestra

TA们的 su

指示代词，“这个，这些”

单数 阳性 este 阴性 esta

复数 阳性 estos 阴性 estas

定冠词，表特指

单数 阳性 el 阴性 la

复数 阳性 los 阴性 las

练习

¿Dónde está tu director?

¿Dónde está tu directora?

¿Dónde están tus directores?

¿Dónde están tus directoras?

¿Dónde está vuestro director?

¿Dónde está vuestra directora?

¿Dónde están vuestros directores?

¿Dónde están vuestras directoras?

Este es mi amigo. El amigo es italiano.

Esta es mi amiga. La amiga es italiana.

Estos son mis amigos. Los amigos son italianos.

Estas son mis amigas. Las amigas son italianas.

Este es el estudiante de chino. El estudiante está muy bien.

Esta es la estudiante de chino. La estudiante está muy bien.

Estos son los estudiantes de chino. Los estudiantes están muy bien.

Estas son las estudiantes de chino. Las estudiantes están muy bien.

打招呼常用语

Buenos días. 早上好。

Buenas tardes. 下午好。

Buenas noches. 晚上好/晚安。

¿Cómo estás? 你好吗？

¿Qué tal? （你/您/你们/诸位）好吗？

Mucho gusto. 很⾼兴（认识你/您）。

Encantado/a. 很⾼兴认识（你/您）。

Adiós. 再见。

Hasta luego. 待会儿见。

Hasta mañana. 明天见。

接打电话

¿Diga? 喂？

¿Con quién hablo? 你是谁？

¿Quién es? 这是谁？

¿De parte de quién? 你是谁？（正式）

句型：主语 + ser + 名词和形容词

注意：西语中形容词要随其修饰的名词进行阴阳性和单复数变化。

  • El cocido y el gazpacho son platos españoles.
  • Neymar y Marcelo son futbolistas brasileños.
  • La pizza y la pasta son comidas italianas.
  • Oxford y Cambridge son ciudades británicas.

Efterårsferie

sydpå 向南 副词

nordpå 向北

østpå 向东

vestpå 向西

lige nu 现在

herfra 从这里

bytur 城市游览

svamp -en -e -ene 蘑菇，真菌，海绵

teater -et, teatre, teatrene 剧院

gå i teatret 去剧院

eller sådan noget 相当于英语的 or something like that

lad os bare gøre det 让我们这样做吧

复习表示建议、提议的表达

Hvad skal vi lave …?

Hvad synes du, vi skal lave?

  • Skal vi ikke + inf.?
  • Vi kan f.eks. + inf.
  • Vi kunne måske + inf.
  • Jeg synes, vi skal/skulle + inf.
  • Hvad siger du til at + inf.?

Svar:

  • Det kan vi godt.
  • Jeg ved ikke rigtig.
  • Det synes jeg ikke.
  • Nej, det har jeg ikke så meget lyst til.

Svar + alternativt forslag:

  • Skal vi ikke hellere …
  • Jeg synes hellere, vi skal …
  • Eller hvad med at inf.

Nyt forslag:

  • Vi kan også …
  • Vi kunne måske også …

作业：剪切并排序，成为一个完整的对话

A: Hvad siger du til at rejse nordpå? Vi kunne for eksempel tage til Nordnorge.

B: Hvad skulle vi lave dér?

A: Vi kunne vandre i bjergene og sove i telt.

B: Nej, det har jeg ikke meget lyst til. Det er for primitivt at sove i telt, og det er for hårdt at vandre. Jeg vil hellere sydpå, hvor der er sol og strand.

A: Jeg ved ikke rigtig. Jeg synes det er kedeligt at ligge på stranden. Skal vi ikke hellere tage på storbyferie?

B: Hvilken storby tænker du på?

A: Hvad siger du til Stockholm?

B: Nej, der har jeg været. Jeg vil hellere til Athen.

A: Nej, der er for mange mennesker. Hvad med Berlin?

B: Ja, det kunne jeg godt tænke mig. Hvordan synes du vi skal bo?

A: Hvad siger du til at prøve Airbnb?

B: Ja, lad os gøre det.

entry.title: 数据挖掘 13 Sequence Segmentation and Similarities
entry.content:
How to segment a sequence of points with an efficient algorithms and how to find similar documents in a linear manner.

2 algorithm.

The first is clustering a sequence to form kkk partitions with a dynamic programming.

The second is an approximation that allows to compute pairwise distance avoiding O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2). The idea is to use efficient signatures and hash the signatures in bands so as similar items will likely end up in the same bucket.

Sequence Segmentation

A sequence is a vector (x1,⋯ ,xn)∈Rn(x_1,\cdots, x_n)\in\mathbb R^n(x1​,⋯,xn​)∈Rn.

Sequence segmentation: Given a set sequence (x1,⋯ ,xn)(x_1,\cdots,x_n)(x1​,⋯,xn​), find kkk contiguous segments that are as homogeneous as possible.

The sequence segmentation problem requires a notion of homogeneity similar to one of clustering. Points in the segment should be subsequences rendering the problem different from that of clustering.

A sequence is homogeneous if its points have a small deviation from the mean. Let D\mathcal DD be a sequence of nnn ddd-dimensional points.

Definition of kkk-segmentation: A kkk-segmentation SSS is a partition of D\mathcal DD into kkk contiguous segments (s1,⋯ ,sk)(s_1,\cdots,s_k)(s1​,⋯,sk​). Each segment sis_isi​ is represented by a ddd-dimensional mean vector μi=1∣s∣∑x∈sx\mu_i=\frac{1}{|s|}\sum_{\mathbb x\in s}\mathbb xμi​=∣s∣1​∑x∈s​x.

The mean vector has the same role of the centroid for kkk-means clustering. The error E(S)E(S)E(S) of a kkk-segmentation SSS is the error of replacing each individual point with the means. Similar to kkk-means, one of the most common errors is sum of squares error:

E(S)=∑s∈S∑s∈S(x−μs)2E(S)=\sum_{s\in S}\sum_{\mathbb s\in S}(\mathbb x-\mu_s)^2E(S)=s∈S∑​s∈S∑​(x−μs​)2

Problem of k-segmentation problem

Given a sequence D=(x1,⋯ ,xn)\mathcal D=(\mathbb x_1,\cdots,\mathbb x_n)D=(x1​,⋯,xn​) of length nnn, find a set of kkk segments SSS of D\mathcal DD s.t. the SSE error is minimized.

A Dynamic Programming Solution

A dynamic programming solution from Bellman solves the kkk-segmentation problem in polynomial time.

The idea is to build the solution bottom-up solving progressively larger instances of the problem.

DP requires the property of optimal sub-problem that states that the solution on a subset of the input is also optimal.

Denote D[1,i]D[1,i]D[1,i] the sub-sequence x1,⋯ ,xi\mathbb x_1,\cdots,\mathbb x_ix1​,⋯,xi​ with i≤ni\le ni≤n. E(i,s)E(i,s)E(i,s) is the error of the optimal segmentation of the sub-sequence D[1,i]D[1,i]D[1,i] with sss segments with s≤ks\le ks≤k. The dynamic programming algorithm follows the recursion

E(i,s)=min⁡s≤j≤i−1(E(j,s−1)+∑j+1≤t≤i(t−μj+1,i)2)E(i,s)=\min_{s\le j\le i-1}\left(E(j,s-1)+\sum_{j+1\le t\le i}(\mathbf t-\mu_{j+1,i})^2\right)E(i,s)=s≤j≤i−1min​(E(j,s−1)+j+1≤t≤i∑​(t−μj+1,i​)2)

In practice we can use a 2-dimensional table that stores in position s,is,is,i the value E(i,s)E(i,s)E(i,s).

Pseudo-code

Input: Sequence D,k,E(⋅)\mathcal D,k,E(\cdot)D,k,E(⋅)

  1. for each i←1⋯ni\gets1\cdots ni←1⋯n do
    • A[1,i]=E(D[1⋯i])A[1,i]=E(D[1\cdots i])A[1,i]=E(D[1⋯i])
  2. for each s←1⋯ks\gets1\cdots ks←1⋯k do
    • A[s,s]=0A[s,s]=0A[s,s]=0
  3. for each s=2⋯ns=2\cdots ns=2⋯n do
    • for each i=s+1,⋯ ,ni=s+1,\cdots,ni=s+1,⋯,n do
      • A[k,i]=min⁡j<i(A[s−1,j]+E(D[j+1⋯i]))A[k,i]=\min_{j\lt i}(A[s-1,j]+E(D[j+1\cdots i]))A[k,i]=minj<i​(A[s−1,j]+E(D[j+1⋯i]))

To recover the actual segmentation, the matrix AAA should store also the values jjj minimizing the error.

Complexity

The algorithm needs to fill O(nk)\mathcal O(nk)O(nk) table, each cell computes the minimum, takes O(n)\mathcal O(n)O(n) cells to check, each of it computes the error in O(n)\mathcal O(n)O(n). Thus total complexity of O(n3k)\mathcal O(n^3k)O(n3k) for naive version.

The errors per cell can be further optimized by noticing that

∑j+1≤t≤i(t−μ[j+1,i])2=∑j+1≤t≤it2−1i−j(∑j+1≤t≤it)2\sum_{j+1\le t\le i}(\mathbf t-\mu_{[j+1,i]})^2=\sum_{j+1\le t\le i}\mathbf t^2-\frac{1}{i-j}(\sum_{j+1\le t\le i}\mathbf t)^2j+1≤t≤i∑​(t−μ[j+1,i]​)2=j+1≤t≤i∑​t2−i−j1​(j+1≤t≤i∑​t)2

that requires the repeated computation of t2\mathbf t^2t2 and t\mathbf tt. These two terms can be easily pre-computed for all i=1⋯ni=1\cdots ni=1⋯n. By this optimization, complexity is reduced to O(n2k)\mathbf O(n^2k)O(n2k).

Heuristic: we can further reduce the computational burden by using greedy approaches or local search that assigns border points randomly and move the in a way to reduce the errors. The total time is O(nk)\mathcal O(nk)O(nk).

Finding Similar Points Efficiently

Comparing each point in the data with other, raising O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2).

Given a dataset D={x1,⋯ ,xn}\mathcal D=\{\mathbb x_1,\cdots,\mathbb x_n\}D={x1​,⋯,xn​} of ddd-dimensional data points, find all the pairs of data point (xi,xj)(\mathbb x_i,\mathbb x_j)(xi​,xj​) s.t. d(xi,xj)≤sd(\mathbb x_i,\mathbb x_j)\le sd(xi​,xj​)≤s for some distance function ddd.

With Locality-Sensitive Hashing, we can get rid of O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2).

LSH 不是 今天上午的随机算法课 才讲的么……这下闭环了。

Definition of Jaccard similarity: of two sets is the size of their intersection sim(C_1,C_2)=|C_1\and C_2|/|C_1\or C_2|. The Jaccard distance is then d(C_1,C_2)=1-|C_1\and C_2|/|C_1\or C_2|.

A large number of documents do not fit into memory and we need a representation of each document that allows for preserving the distances while considerably reducing the memory footprint. In order to achieve such a gold, we use the 3 steps:

  1. Shingling: Convert documents to sets.
  2. Min-hashing: Convert large sets to short signatures, while preserving similarity.
  3. LSH: Focus on pairs of signatures likely to be from similar documents.

Shingling

A kkk-shingle is a set of kkk tokens that appear in the document.

Idea: we return a large number of sparse vector with low similarity.

For instance, the set of 222-shingle for document D1=abcabD_1=abcabD1​=abcab is S(D1)={ab,bc,ca}S(D_1)=\{ab,bc,ca\}S(D1​)={ab,bc,ca}.

Long shingles can be easily compressed by hashing. Documents are compared through the hash values. Finally each document is a binary vector in the space of kkk-shingle in which a shingle is a dimension.

We assume that documents have a large number of common shingles if they are similar. However, kkk is a critical choice to compare documents. A small kkk leads to a large number of similar documents. As rule of thumb k=5,10k=5,10k=5,10 is a reasonable choice for short/large documents.

Shingling doesn’t solve the problem of a large number of similarity computation.

Min-hash

The document is converted into a set of shingles and consequently as a binary vector, where each dimension is a shingle and a 111 in position iii of document jjj indicates that the document contains the shingle iii. This way can we represent our dataset as a matrix where each row represents.

Computing Jaccard similarity in such a matrix relies on simple bit-wise AND, intersection and OR.

Min-Hashing is used for faster comparison. It converts the binary representation into small signatures through hashing. The key idea is to hash each column to a small signatures h(C)h(C)h(C) s.t.

  • h(C)h(C)h(C) is small enough that the signature fits in RAM
  • sim(C1,C2)sim(C_1,C_2)sim(C1​,C2​) is the same as the similarity of signatures h(C1),h(C2)h(C_1),h(C_2)h(C1​),h(C2​).

Definition of min-hash function: The hash function hπ(C)h_\pi(C)hπ​(C) returns the index of the first row in which column CCC has value 111.

hπ(C)=min⁡π(C)h_\pi(C)=\min_\pi(C)hπ​(C)=πmin​(C)

Hash function is a approximation of a set.

Min-hash preserves the property that Pr⁡[hπ(C1)=hπ(C2)]=sim(C1,C2)\Pr[h_\pi(C_1)=h_\pi(C_2)]=sim(C_1,C_2)Pr[hπ​(C1​)=hπ​(C2​)]=sim(C1​,C2​).

A trick

For each column CCC, and hash function, kik_iki​ keep a slot for the min-hash value. Initialize Sig(C)[i]=∞Sig(C)[i]=\inftySig(C)[i]=∞, then scan rows looking for 111s. How to choose kik_iki​? Using universal hashing.

又是随机算法前面学过的东西。

LSH

LSH tackles the problem of the comparison by hashing the signatures in an appropriate manner.

Intuition: use a function f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) to determine whether xxx and yyy is a candidate pair whose similarity must be evaluated. For Min-hash matrices we hash the columns of the signature matrix MMM to different buckets. If two documents hashes into the same buckets, they become a candidate pair with similarity sim≥thresholdsim\ge thresholdsim≥threshold.

LSH works:

  • Pick a similarity threshold sss.
  • The columns of xxx and yyy of MMM are a candidate pair if their signatures agree on at least a fraction sss of their rows. M(i,x)=M(i,y)M(i,x)=M(i,y)M(i,x)=M(i,y) for at least a fraction sss of iii.
  • The idea is to hash columns of signatures matrix MMM several times. Similar columns should be likely to hash to the same bucket with high probability.

LSH partitions MMM’s columns into bbb bands each of rrr rows. For each band, compute a signatures using a hash function with kkk buckets, where kkk is arbitrarily large. The candidate column pairs are those that hash to the same bucket for at least 111 band. Tune bbb and rrr to catch most similar pairs, few non-similar pairs.

How to choose bbb and rrr?

Balances false positives / negatives.

We need to strike a trade-off with the number of bands and the number of rows.

As bbb increases, the method becomes more reliable, but the time increases as well.

If t=sim(C1,C2)t=sim(C_1,C_2)t=sim(C1​,C2​) the probability that all rows in a band are equal is trt^rtr and probability that some row in a band are different is 1−tr1-t^r1−tr.

As such the probability that no band is identical is (1−rt)b(1-r^t)^b(1−rt)b that leads to (1−(1−rt)b)(1-(1-r^t)^b)(1−(1−rt)b) the probability that at least 111 band is identical.

Pros and Cons

👍Finds similar items in linear time

👍Easy and fast to implement

👍Generalizes to other similarity measures

👎Performance depend on the choice of b,rb,rb,r

👎Requres a fairly large number of buckets

entry.title: Fair Division for 2 Strategic Agents with Divisible Items
entry.content:
For randomized fair division with indivisible items, we consider its ex-ante fairness. Indeed when it comes to expected valuation (or payoff), it’s equivalent to fair division with divisible items.

Consider fair division with divisible items among only 2 AGENT.

The input valuation for each agent is the ordinal preference ≻i\succ_i≻i​.

We want to explore to what extent agent can manipulate by misreporting preference profile to gain more share of items with higher priority.

The source code and experiment results is available in my GitHub Repo

Reporting State Graph

A (directed) reporting state graph is defined: G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E).

VVV denote the set of all the possible preference input.

EEE denotes the set of all edges. A directed edge e=(v1,v2)e=(v_1,v_2)e=(v1​,v2​) denotes there exist a agent in reporting state v1v_1v1​, who can better off by deviating its report to state v2v_2v2​.

(In this scenario, better off means that agent strictly SD-prefer v2v_2v2​ to v1v_1v1​)

  • For case of 3 items, there are 3!×3!=363!\times3!=363!×3!=36 reporting state vertices.
  • For case of 4 items, there are 4!×4!=5764!\times4!=5764!×4!=576 reporting state vertices.

❓Is there any cycle in the reporting state graph?

# States Can be Reduced

Without loss of generality, by rotational symmetry,

  • For case of 3 items, it suffices to analyze only 3!=63!=63!=6 reporting state vertices.

    For example 1:g1≻g2≻g3,2:g1≻g2≻g31:g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3,2:g_1\succ g_2\succ g_31:g1​≻g2​≻g3​,2:g1​≻g2​≻g3​ is equivalent to 1:g1≻g3≻g2,2:g1≻g3≻g21:g_1\succ g_3\succ g_2,2:g_1\succ g_3\succ g_21:g1​≻g3​≻g2​,2:g1​≻g3​≻g2​.

  • Analogously, for case of 444 items, it’s enough to analyze 4!=244!=244!=24 reporting states.

2 Agents, 3 Items

Without loss of generality, by symmetry of two agents, it suffice to check only one agent.

Analysis Case-by-case

For the scenario of 2 agents with 3 divisible goods.

Assume the 3 items are g1,g2,g3g_1,g_2,g_3g1​,g2​,g3​, 2 agent 1,21,21,2.

  • There are 363636 cases in total, but by rotational symmetry, it can be reduced to 666 cases.
  • For example 1:g1≻g2≻g3,2:g1≻g2≻g31:g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3,2:g_1\succ g_2\succ g_31:g1​≻g2​≻g3​,2:g1​≻g2​≻g3​ is equivalent to 1:g1≻g3≻g2,2:g1≻g3≻g21:g_1\succ g_3\succ g_2,2:g_1\succ g_3\succ g_21:g1​≻g3​≻g2​,2:g1​≻g3​≻g2​.
  • The 666 cases are in the following (Fix the ordinal preference on agent 1 on g1≻g2≻g3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1​≻g2​≻g3​, we analysis agent 2 for all permutations on preference):

  1. agent 1’s true preference: g1≻g2≻g3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1​≻g2​≻g3​

    agent 2’s true preference: g1≻g2≻g3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1​≻g2​≻g3​

    agent 1 gets: [50.0,50.0,50.0][50.0, 50.0, 50.0][50.0,50.0,50.0]

    agent 2 gets: [50.0,50.0,50.0][50.0, 50.0, 50.0][50.0,50.0,50.0]

    • Best response for agent 2? Yes.

      Because there are no other preference profile of player 2 inducing high sum of share of first kkk item for k=[3]k=[3]k=[3].

  2. agent1’s true preference: g1≻g2≻g3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1​≻g2​≻g3​

    agent2’s true preference: g1≻g3≻g2g_1\succ g_3\succ g_2g1​≻g3​≻g2​

    agent1 gets: [50.0,100,0][50.0, 100, 0][50.0,100,0]

    agent2 gets: [50.0,0,100][50.0, 0, 100][50.0,0,100]

    • Best response for agent 2? Yes.

      First observe that by eating protocol, each agent exactly gain the total share of 150150150 item.

      The top priority of both agents are g1g_1g1​, thus agent 2 can’t manipulate to gain higher than 505050 share of g1g_1g1​ when agent 1 reports truthfully by putting g1g_1g1​ on its top priority.

    • Agent 2 in case 5 has an incentive to deviate to case 2. Then it’s natural to ask whether it’s the best response for agent 1.

      The answer is Yes.

      • Agent 1 must put g1g_1g1​ on top priority, otherwise it will loss the share of its favorite g1g_1g1​.
      • If agent 111 switch the position of g2g_2g2​ and g3g_3g3​, it will loss the share of second priority g2g_2g2​.

  3. agent 1’s true preference: g1≻g2≻g3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1​≻g2​≻g3​

    agent 2’s true preference: g2≻g1≻g3g_2\succ g_1\succ g_3g2​≻g1​≻g3​

    agent 1 gets: [100,0,50.0][100, 0, 50.0][100,0,50.0]

    agent 2 gets: [0,100,50.0][0, 100, 50.0][0,100,50.0]

    • Best response for agent 2? Yes.

      Here any other misreport which promote share of g1g_1g1​ will hurt the 100100100 share of g2g_2g2​.

  4. agent 1’s true preference: g1≻g2≻g3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1​≻g2​≻g3​

    agent 2’s true preference: g2≻g3≻g1g_2\succ g_3\succ g_1g2​≻g3​≻g1​

    agent1 gets: [100,0,50.0][100, 0, 50.0][100,0,50.0]

    agent 2 gets: [0,100,50.0][0, 100, 50.0][0,100,50.0]

    • Best response for agent 2? Yes.

      Indeed, it’s the best outcome for both agent: 100100100 share of top priority, 505050 share of second priority.

  5. agent 1’s true preference: g1≻g2≻g3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1​≻g2​≻g3​

    agent 2’s true preference: g3≻g1≻g2g_3\succ g_1\succ g_2g3​≻g1​≻g2​

    agent1 gets: [100,50.0,0][100, 50.0, 0][100,50.0,0]

    agent2 gets: [0,50.0,100][0, 50.0, 100][0,50.0,100]

    • Best response for agent 2? NO!!!

      By misreporting g1≻g3≻g2g_1\succ g_3\succ g_2g1​≻g3​≻g2​, the eating protocol allocates:

      • agent 1 gets: [50.0,100,0][50.0, 100, 0][50.0,100,0]
      • agent 2 gets: [50.0,0,100][50.0, 0, 100][50.0,0,100]

      Which is strictly better off w.r.t. agent 2.

  6. agent 1’s true preference: g1≻g2≻g3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1​≻g2​≻g3​

    agent 2’s true preference: g3≻g2≻g1g_3\succ g_2\succ g_1g3​≻g2​≻g1​

    agent 1 gets: [100,50.0,0][100, 50.0, 0][100,50.0,0]

    agent 2 gets: [0,50.0,100][0, 50.0, 100][0,50.0,100]

    • Best response for agent 222? Yes.

      Indeed, it’s the best outcome for both agent: 100100100 share of top priority, 505050 share of second priority.

Graph of reporting states

There are 3!×3!=363!\times3!=363!×3!=36 reporting states VVV. An directed edge in the graph e=(v1,v2)∈Ee=(v_1,v_2)\in Ee=(v1​,v2​)∈E means there are a agent in reporting state node v1v_1v1​ has an incentive to deviate to reporting state v2v_2v2​.

By the analysis for 6 cases above, there are no cycle in the graph.

Case of 4 Items

Fix agent 1 with preference g1≻g2≻g3≻g4g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3\succ g_4g1​≻g2​≻g3​≻g4​.

For agent 2, the reporting states graph is:

  flowchart LRsubgraph TB ["incentive to deviate"]0312 --> 01322013 --> 02132013 --> 02312031 --> 02132031 --> 02313012 --> 01323012 --> 03123012 --> 03213012 --> 10323012 --> 13023012 --> 13203021 --> 03123021 --> 03213102 --> 01323102 --> 10323102 --> 13023102 --> 13203120 --> 10323120 --> 13023120 --> 1320endsubgraph BT ["prefer truth-telling"]01230132021302310321102310321203123013021320210321302301231032013210end

Observation: There are also no cycle in the reporting states graph for 4 items.

Case of 5 Items

As the # agent growth, the state grows exponentially.

Fix agent 1 with preference g1≻g2≻g3≻g4≻g5g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3\succ g_4\succ g_5g1​≻g2​≻g3​≻g4​≻g5​.

For agent 2, the reporting states graph contains 469 edges. But no cycle exists.

My Conjectures

🤔In 2 strategic agents with n≥4n\ge4n≥4 divisible items, There is no cycle in the corresponding reporting-state-graph.

entry.title: 随机算法 11 Randomized Rounding for MAX SAT
entry.content:
MAX SAT and MAX CUT

randomized ½ approximation for each problem

MAX SAT

aka maximum satisfiability problem

  • Input consists of nnn Boolean variables x1,⋯ ,xnx_1,\cdots,x_nx1​,⋯,xn​, mmm clauses C1,⋯ ,CmC_1,\cdots,C_mC1​,⋯,Cm​.
    • Clauses CjC_jCj​ consist of some number of variables and \or and a non-negative weight wjw_jwj​.
  • The objective of the problem is to find an assignment of xix_ixi​ that maximizes the weight of the satisfied clauses.
  • A clause is said to be satisfied if one of the unnegated variables is set to true, or one of the negated variables is set to false.

Some terminology:

  • literal. A variable xix_ixi​ or a negated variable xˉi\bar x_ixˉi​ is a literal, so that each clause consists of some number of literals.
    • xix_ixi​ is called positive literal
    • xˉi\bar x_ixˉi​ is called negative literal
  • length. The number of literals in a clause. Length of CiC_iCi​ is lil_ili​.
  • Clause of length 1 is unit clause.

WLOG, assume that no literal is repeated in a clause, at most one of xix_ixi​ and xˉi\bar x_ixˉi​ appears in a clause.

Assume the clauses are distinct.

A very straightforward use of randomization: set each xix_ixi​ to true independently with probability 1/21/21/2.

🤔Theorem 1. Setting each xix_ixi​ to true with probability 1/21/21/2 independently gives a randomized 1/21/21/2-approximation algorithm for the MAX SAT problem.

Define indicator variable YjY_jYj​: 111 if clause jjj is satisfied and 000 otherwise.

Let WWW be a random variable that is equal to the total weight of the satisfied clauses, so that W=∑jwjYjW=\sum_jw_jY_jW=∑j​wj​Yj​.

Let OPTOPTOPT denote the optimum value of the MAX SAT instance. Then, by linearity of expectation, and the definition of the expectation of 0-1 random variable, we know

E[W]=∑j=1mwjE[Yj]=∑j=1mwjPr⁡[Cj is satisfied].\mathbb E[W]=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\mathbb E[Y_j]=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\Pr[C_j\text{ is satisfied}].E[W]=j=1∑m​wj​E[Yj​]=j=1∑m​wj​Pr[Cj​ is satisfied].

For each CjC_jCj​, the probability that it is not satisfied is the probability that each positive literal in CjC_jCj​ is set to false and each negative literal is set to true, each of which happens with probability 1/21/21/2. Hence,

Pr⁡[Cj is satisfied]=(1−(12)lj)≥12,\Pr[C_j\text{ is satisfied}]=\left(1-(\frac{1}{2})^{l_j}\right)\ge\frac{1}{2},Pr[Cj​ is satisfied]=(1−(21​)lj​)≥21​,

where the last inequality is a consequence of the fact that lj≥1l_j\ge1lj​≥1. Hence,

E[W]≥12∑j=1mwj≥12OPT,\mathbb E[W]\ge\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\ge\frac{1}{2}OPT,E[W]≥21​j=1∑m​wj​≥21​OPT,

where the last inequality follows from the fact that the total weight is an easy upper bound on the optimal value, since each weight is assumed to be non-negative.

If lj≥kl_j\ge klj​≥k for each clause jjj, the algorithm is a (1−(12)k)\left(1-(\frac{1}{2})^k\right)(1−(21​)k)-approximation algorithm for such instances. Thus the longer the clauses, the better the approximation.

Consider lj=3l_j=3lj​=3 for all clauses, the problem turns into MAX E3SAT. By analysis above, this randomized algorithm gives guarantee of 7/87/87/8 approximation. Nothing better is possible for these instances unless P=NPP=NPP=NP.

🤔Theorem 2. If there is an (78+ϵ)(\frac{7}{8}+\epsilon)(87​+ϵ)-approximation algorithm for MAX E3SAT for any constant ϵ>0\epsilon\gt 0ϵ>0, then P=NPP=NPP=NP.

MAX CUT

aka maximum cut problem

In this problem. the input is an undirected graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E), along with a non-negative weight wij≥0w_{ij}\ge0wij​≥0 for each edge (i,j)∈E(i,j)\in E(i,j)∈E. The goal is to partition the vertex set into two parts UUU and W=V−UW=V-UW=V−U, so as to maximize the weight of edges whose two endpoints are in different parts, one in UUU and another in WWW.

An edge with endpoints in both UUU and WWW is in the cut. In the case wij=1w_{ij}=1wij​=1 for each edge ∈E\in E∈E, we have an unweighted MAX CUT problem.

We place each vertex v∈Vv\in Vv∈V into UUU independently with probability 1/21/21/2. As with the MAX SAT algorithm, this can be viewed as sampling a solution uniformly form the space of all possible solutions.

🤔Theorem 3. If we place each vertex v∈Vv\in Vv∈V into UUU independently with probability 1/21/21/2, then we obtain a randomized 1/21/21/2-approximation algorithm for the maximum cut problem.

Consider a random variable XijX_{ij}Xij​ that is 111 if edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) is in the cut, and 000 otherwise.

Let ZZZ be the random variable equal to the total weight of edges in the cut, so that Z=∑(i,j)∈EwijXijZ=\sum_{(i,j)\in E}w_{ij}X_{ij}Z=∑(i,j)∈E​wij​Xij​.

Let OPTOPTOPT denote the optimal value of the maximum cut instance. Then, as before, by linearity of expectation and the definition of expectation of a 0-1 random variable, we get that

E[Z]=∑(i,j)∈EwijE[Xij]=∑(i,j)∈EwijPr⁡[(i,j) in cut].\mathbb E[Z]=\sum_{(i,j)\in E}w_{ij}\mathbb E[X_{ij}]=\sum_{(i,j)\in E}w_{ij}\Pr[(i,j)\text{ in cut}].E[Z]=(i,j)∈E∑​wij​E[Xij​]=(i,j)∈E∑​wij​Pr[(i,j) in cut].

The probability that a specific edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) is in the cut: since the 2 endpoints are placed in the sets independently, they are in different sets with probability equal to 1/21/21/2. Hence,

E[Z]=12∑(i,j)∈Ewij≥12OPT,\mathbb E[Z]=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{(i,j)\in E}w_{ij}\ge\frac{1}{2}OPT,E[Z]=21​(i,j)∈E∑​wij​≥21​OPT,

where the inequality follows directly from the fact that the sum of the non-negative weights of all edges is obviously an upper bound on the weight of the edges in an optimal cut.

Derandomization

Randomized algorithm for MAX SAT can be derandomized by replacing the randomized decision of whether to set xix_ixi​ to true with a deterministic one that will preserve the expected value of the solution. The decisions will be made sequentially.

Assume that x1x_1x1​ is fixed, and other variables will be set true with probability 1/21/21/2. Intuitively we should choose the value of x1x_1x1​ which maximize the expected value of WWW. In this way, we should maintain the algorithm that the expected value is at least half the optimum, while having fewer random variables left.

If E[W∣x1←true]≥E[W∣x1←false]\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets true]\ge\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets false]E[W∣x1​←true]≥E[W∣x1​←false], then we set x1x_1x1​ to true, otherwise false. Then

E[W]=E[W∣x1←ture]Pr⁡[x1←true]+E[W∣x←false]Pr⁡[x1←flase]=12(E[W∣x1←true]+E[W∣x1←false])\mathbb E[W]=\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets ture]\Pr[x_1\gets true]+\mathbb E[W|x\gets false]\Pr[x_1\gets flase]\\=\frac{1}{2}(\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets true]+\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets false])E[W]=E[W∣x1​←ture]Pr[x1​←true]+E[W∣x←false]Pr[x1​←flase]=21​(E[W∣x1​←true]+E[W∣x1​←false])

By induction, we can set the sequence of variables better than 1/21/21/2.

Flipping Biased Coins

Consider MAX SAT instance with no unit clauses xˉi\bar x_ixˉi​. (This condition can be moved)

Suppose we set each xix_ixi​ to be true independently with probability p>12p\gt\frac{1}{2}p>21​, then the probability that any given clause is satisfied is at least min⁡(p,1−p2)\min(p,1-p^2)min(p,1−p2) for MAX SAT instances with no negated unit clauses.

假设这些布尔表达式不含有单个非变量。

对于只含一个变量的布尔表达式，满足的概率为 ppp.

对于含有至少两个变量的布尔表达式，假设 xix_ixi​ 有 aaa 个，xˉj\bar x_jxˉj​ 有 bbb 个，则该表达式不满足的概率为：

Pr⁡[Ck not satisfied]=(1−p)apb≤pa+b≤p2∴Pr⁡[Ck satisfied]≥1−p2\Pr[C_k\text{ not satisfied}]=(1-p)^ap^b\le p^{a+b}\le p^2\\\therefore\Pr[C_k\text{ satisfied}]\ge 1-p^2Pr[Ck​ not satisfied]=(1−p)apb≤pa+b≤p2∴Pr[Ck​ satisfied]≥1−p2

现在就需要将 min⁡(p,1−p2)\min(p,1-p^2)min(p,1−p2) 最大化。

Best performance is p=1−p2⇒p≈0.618p=1-p^2\Rarr p\approx0.618p=1−p2⇒p≈0.618.

🤔Theorem 4. Setting each xix_ixi​ to true with probability ppp independently gives a randomized min⁡(p,1−p2)\min(p,1-p^2)min(p,1−p2)-approximation algorithm for MAX SAT instances with no negated unit clauses.

Let viv_ivi​ be the weight of the unit clause xˉi\bar x_ixˉi​ if it exists in the instance, and let viv_ivi​ be zero otherwise.

OPTOPTOPT has a tighter bound: OPT≤∑j=1mwj−∑i=1nviOPT\le\sum_{j=1}^mw_j-\sum_{i=1}^nv_iOPT≤∑j=1m​wj​−∑i=1n​vi​.

Let UUU be the set of indices of clauses of the instance excluding unit clauses of the form xˉi\bar x_ixˉi​. WLOG the weight of each clause xˉi\bar x_ixˉi​ is no greater than the weight of clause xix_ixi​. Thus ∑j∈Uwj=∑j=1mwj−∑i=1nvi\sum_{j\in U}w_j=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j-\sum_{i=1}^nv_i∑j∈U​wj​=∑j=1m​wj​−∑i=1n​vi​. Each xix_ixi​ is set to true with probability 0.6180.6180.618. So the algorithm produces

E[W]=∑j=1mwjPr⁡[Cj satisfied]≥∑j∈UmwjPr⁡[Cj satisfied]≥p⋅∑j∈Uwj=p⋅(∑j=1mwj−∑i=1nvi)≥p⋅OPT.\mathbb E[W]=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\Pr[C_j\text{ satisfied}]\\\ge\sum_{j\in U}^mw_j\Pr[C_j\text{ satisfied}]\\\ge p\cdot\sum_{j\in U}w_j\\=p\cdot(\sum_{j=1}^mw_j-\sum_{i=1}^nv_i)\ge p\cdot OPT.E[W]=j=1∑m​wj​Pr[Cj​ satisfied]≥j∈U∑m​wj​Pr[Cj​ satisfied]≥p⋅j∈U∑​wj​=p⋅(j=1∑m​wj​−i=1∑n​vi​)≥p⋅OPT.

This algorithm can be derandomized using the method of conditional expectations.

Randomized Rounding

Biasing probability with which we set xix_ixi​ true yields an improved approximation algorithm. However, we gave each variable the same bias. We can do better by giving each variable its own bias!

Idea of randomized rounding:

  • First set up an integer programming formulation of the problem at hand in which there are 0-1 integer variables. 0-1 variable yiy_iyi​ for each Boolean variable xix_ixi​ s.t. yi=1y_i=1yi​=1 corresponds to xix_ixi​ set true.
  • The integer program is relaxed to a linear program by replacing the constraints yi∈{0,1}y_i\in\{0,1\}yi​∈{0,1} with 0≤yi≤10\le y_i\le 10≤yi​≤1.
  • The fractional value yi∗y_i^*yi∗​ is interpreted as the probability that yiy_iyi​ should be set to 111. In this case we set each xix_ixi​ to true with probability yi∗y_i^*yi∗​ independently.

For MAX SAT problem, in addition to the variables yiy_iyi​, we introduce a variable zjz_jzj​ for each CjC_jCj​ that will be 111 if the clause is satisfied and 000 otherwise. For each clause CjC_jCj​ let PjP_jPj​ be the indices of the variables xix_ixi​ that are positive, NjN_jNj​ be negated in the clause.

We denote the clause CjC_jCj​ by

\bigvee_{i\in P_j}x_i\or\bigvee_{i\in N_j}\bar x_i.

Then the inequality

∑i∈Pjyi+∑i∈Nj(1−yi)≥zj\sum_{i\in P_j}y_i+\sum_{i\in N_j}(1-y_i)\ge z_ji∈Pj​∑​yi​+i∈Nj​∑​(1−yi​)≥zj​

must hold for CjC_jCj​ since if each variable that occurs positively in the clause is set to false and each variable that occurs negatively is set to true, then the clause is not satisfied, and zjz_jzj​ must be 000.

This yields integer programming formulation of MAX SAT problem:

  • maximize ∑j=1mwjzj\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j∑j=1m​wj​zj​
  • subject to ∑i∈Pjyi+∑i∈Nj(1−yi)≥zj\sum_{i\in P_j}y_i+\sum_{i\in N_j}(1-y_i)\ge z_j∑i∈Pj​​yi​+∑i∈Nj​​(1−yi​)≥zj​, \forall C_j=\bigvee_{i\in P_j}x_i\or\bigvee_{i\in N_j}\bar x_i,
  • yi∈{0,1},i=1,⋯ ,ny_i\in\{0,1\},i=1,\cdots,nyi​∈{0,1},i=1,⋯,n
  • 0≤zj≤1,j=1,⋯ ,m0\le z_j\le 1,j=1,\cdots,m0≤zj​≤1,j=1,⋯,m

ZLP∗Z^*_{LP}ZLP∗​ is the optimum value of this linear program LPLPLP, then clearly the optimum value of integer program (IP) ZIP∗=OPTZ^*_{IP}=OPTZIP∗​=OPT.

Let (y∗,z∗)(y^*,z^*)(y∗,z∗) be the optimum value of solution to the linear programming, relaxation. Consider the result of using randomized rounding, and setting xix_ixi​ to true with probability yi∗y_i^*yi∗​ independently. Before we can begin the analysis, we will need 2 facts. The first is commonly called the arithmetic-geometric mean inequality, because it compares the arithmetic and geometric means of a set of numbers.

∏i=1kaik≤1k∑i=1kai\sqrt[k]{\prod_{i=1}^ka_i}\le\frac{1}{k}\sum_{i=1}^ka_iki=1∏k​ai​​≤k1​i=1∑k​ai​

If f′′(x)≤0∀x∈[0,1],f(0)=a,f(1)=b+af''(x)\le0\forall x\in[0,1],f(0)=a,f(1)=b+af′′(x)≤0∀x∈[0,1],f(0)=a,f(1)=b+a, then f(x)≥bx+a∀x∈[0,1]f(x)\ge bx+a\forall x\in[0,1]f(x)≥bx+a∀x∈[0,1].

🤔Theorem 5. Randomized rounding gives a randomized (1−1e)(1-\frac{1}{e})(1−e1​)-approximation algorithm for MAX SAT.

Applying arithmetic-geometric mean inequality:

Pr⁡[Cj not satisfied]=∏i∈Pj(1−yi∗)∏i∈Njyi∗≤[1lj(∑i∈Pj(1−yi∗)+∑i∈Njyi∗)]lj\Pr[C_j\text{ not satisfied}]=\prod_{i\in P_j}(1-y_i^*)\prod_{i\in N_j}y_i^*\\\le\left[\frac{1}{l_j}(\sum_{i\in P_j}(1-y_i^*)+\sum_{i\in N_j}y_i^*)\right]^{l_j}Pr[Cj​ not satisfied]=i∈Pj​∏​(1−yi∗​)i∈Nj​∏​yi∗​≤⎣⎢⎡​lj​1​(i∈Pj​∑​(1−yi∗​)+i∈Nj​∑​yi∗​)⎦⎥⎤​lj​

By rearranging terms,

[1lj(∑i∈Pj(1−yi∗)+∑i∈Njyi∗)]lj=[1−1lj(∑i∈Nj(1−yi∗)+∑i∈Pjyi∗)]lj\left[\frac{1}{l_j}(\sum_{i\in P_j}(1-y_i^*)+\sum_{i\in N_j}y_i^*)\right]^{l_j}=\left[1-\frac{1}{l_j}(\sum_{i\in N_j}(1-y_i^*)+\sum_{i\in P_j}y_i^*)\right]^{l_j}⎣⎢⎡​lj​1​(i∈Pj​∑​(1−yi∗​)+i∈Nj​∑​yi∗​)⎦⎥⎤​lj​=⎣⎢⎡​1−lj​1​(i∈Nj​∑​(1−yi∗​)+i∈Pj​∑​yi∗​)⎦⎥⎤​lj​

By the inequality Optimum of LP ≥\ge≥ Optimum of IP, we see

Pr⁡[Cj not satisfied]≤(1−zj∗lj)lj.\Pr[C_j\text{ not satisfied}]\le\left(1-\frac{z_j^*}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}.Pr[Cj​ not satisfied]≤(1−lj​zj∗​​)lj​.

Function f(zj∗)=1−(1−zj∗lj)ljf(z_j^*)=1-\left(1-\frac{z_j^*}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}f(zj∗​)=1−(1−lj​zj∗​​)lj​ is concave for lj≥1l_j\ge1lj​≥1, then

Pr⁡[Cj satisfied]≥1−(1−zj∗lj)lj≥[(1−1lj)lj]zj∗.\Pr[C_j\text{ satisfied}]\ge1-\left(1-\frac{z_j^*}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\\\ge\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\right]z_j^*.Pr[Cj​ satisfied]≥1−(1−lj​zj∗​​)lj​≥[(1−lj​1​)lj​]zj∗​.

Therefore the expected value of the randomized rounding algorithm is

E[W]=∑j=1mwjPr⁡[Cj satisfied]≥∑j=1mwjzj∗[(1−1lj)lj]≥min⁡k≥1[(1−1k)k]∑j=1mwjzj∗.\mathbb E[W]=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\Pr[C_j\text{ satisfied}]\\\ge\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\right]\\\ge\min_{k\ge1}\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{k}\right)^{k}\right]\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*.E[W]=j=1∑m​wj​Pr[Cj​ satisfied]≥j=1∑m​wj​zj∗​[(1−lj​1​)lj​]≥k≥1min​[(1−k1​)k]j=1∑m​wj​zj∗​.

[(1−1k)k]\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{k}\right)^{k}\right][(1−k1​)k] is non-increasing. It approaches 1−1e1-\frac{1}{e}1−e1​ from above as kkk tends to infinity. Thus we have

E[W]≥min⁡k≥1[(1−1k)k]∑j=1mwjzj∗≥(1−1e)OPT.\mathbb E[W]\ge\min_{k\ge1}\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{k}\right)^{k}\right]\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*\ge(1-\frac{1}{e})OPT.E[W]≥k≥1min​[(1−k1​)k]j=1∑m​wj​zj∗​≥(1−e1​)OPT.

This randomized rounding algorithm can be derandomized in the standard way using the method of conditional expectations.

这个证明不太优雅，其实可以用 ex≥x+1e^x\ge x+1ex≥x+1 进行放缩，将乘积化为 eee 的指数和的形式。

然后再用线性规划的结果至少优于整数线性规划的结果，得到 Pr⁡[Ci(x)=1]≥1−exp⁡(−zj∗)\Pr[C_i(x)=1]\ge1-\exp(-z_j^*)Pr[Ci​(x)=1]≥1−exp(−zj∗​)。

Choosing the Better of 2 Solutions

Consider a given clause CjC_jCj​ of length ljl_jlj​. The randomized rounding algorithm satisfies the clause with probability at least [(1−1lj)lj]zj∗\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\right]z_j^*[(1−lj​1​)lj​]zj∗​, while the unbiased randomized algorithm satisfies the clause with probability 1−2−lj≥(1−2−lj)zj∗1-2^{-l_j}\ge(1-2^{-l_j})z_j^*1−2−lj​≥(1−2−lj​)zj∗​.

When the clause is short, it is very likely to be satisfied by the randomized rounding algorithm, tough not by the unbiased randomized algorithm. When the clause is long, the opposite is true.

🤔Theorem 6. Choosing the better of the two solutions given by the randomized rounding algorithm and the unbiased randomized algorithm yields a randomized 3/43/43/4-approximation algorithm for MAX SAT.

Let W1W_1W1​ be a random variable denoting the value of the solution by randomized rounding algorithm.

Let W2W_2W2​ be the results of unbiased randomized algorithm. To show:

E[max⁡(W1,W2)]≥34OPT\mathbb E[\max(W_1,W_2)]\ge\frac{3}{4}OPT\\E[max(W1​,W2​)]≥43​OPT

Observe that

E[max⁡(W1,W2)]≥E[12(W1+W2)]=12E[W1]+12E[W2]≥12∑j=1mwjzj∗[(1−1lj)lj]+12∑j=1mwj(1−2−lj)≥∑j=1mwjzj∗[12(1−(1−1lj)lj)+12(1−2−lj)].\mathbb E[\max(W_1,W_2)]\ge\mathbb E[\frac{1}{2}(W_1+W_2)]\\=\frac{1}{2}\mathbb E[W_1]+\frac{1}{2}\mathbb E[W_2]\\\ge\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\right]+\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^mw_j(1-2^{-l_j})\\\ge\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(1-(1-\frac{1}{l_j})^{l_j}\right)+\frac{1}{2}(1-2^{-l_j})\right].E[max(W1​,W2​)]≥E[21​(W1​+W2​)]=21​E[W1​]+21​E[W2​]≥21​j=1∑m​wj​zj∗​[(1−lj​1​)lj​]+21​j=1∑m​wj​(1−2−lj​)≥j=1∑m​wj​zj∗​[21​(1−(1−lj​1​)lj​)+21​(1−2−lj​)].

Claim that

[12(1−(1−1lj)lj)+12(1−2−lj)]≥34\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(1-(1-\frac{1}{l_j})^{l_j}\right)+\frac{1}{2}(1-2^{-l_j})\right]\ge\frac{3}{4}[21​(1−(1−lj​1​)lj​)+21​(1−2−lj​)]≥43​

for all positive integers ljl_jlj​.

Notice that taking the best solution of the two derandomized algorithms gives at least half of sum of two results.

Thus taking the best solution of the two derandomized algorithms is a deterministic 3/43/43/4-approximation algorithm.

Non-linear Randomized Rounding

3/43/43/4-approximation algorithm for MAX SAT can be obtained by using randomized rounding with a non-linear function fff.

entry.title: 数据挖掘 12 Frequent Itemsets and Association Rules
entry.content:
Frequent itemsets and association rules.

This problem aims to find a set of items that are bought together. These itemsets can be efficiently mined by exploiting the apriori principle of the support measure.

Frequent Itemsets Mining

Frequent itemsets: collections of objects that appear a minimum number of times in the baskets of the customers.

Set of ddd items I\mathcal II, set of nnn transactions identifiers T\mathcal TT.

Dataset D\mathcal DD is a set of pairs (i,t)∈I×T(i,t)\in\mathcal I\times\mathcal T(i,t)∈I×T.

A basket is a transaction-set t(D)={i1,⋯ ,i∣t∣}t(\mathcal D)=\{i_1,\cdots,i_{|t|}\}t(D)={i1​,⋯,i∣t∣​}.

An itemset is a subset of I⊆2II\subseteq2^\mathcal II⊆2I items, where 2I2^\mathcal I2I is the powerset of all subsets of I\mathcal II.

Definition of support: For an itemset III we define the support σ(I)\sigma(I)σ(I) as the number of transactions that contain itemset III, i.e., σ(I)=∣{t∈T∣I⊆t(D)}∣\sigma(I)=|\{t\in\mathcal T|I\subseteq t(\mathcal D)\}|σ(I)=∣{t∈T∣I⊆t(D)}∣.

Frequent itemset mining problem finds all the itemsets I⊆2II\subseteq 2^\mathcal II⊆2I that have a support σ(I)≥minsup\sigma(I)\ge minsupσ(I)≥minsup. The support can be expressed as a number or a percentage, similarly to frequent subgraph mining in last lecture. If we have ddd items, we have potentially 2d2^d2d itemsets. Itemsets are typically represented in a lattice structure, in which the root is empty, and each node is the union of itemsets in the parent nodes. The question is how do we find frequent itemsets efficiently.

A naive solution. To count each itemset individually. This requires to construct 2d2^d2d itemsets and compte the frequency for each of them, reaching O(2dnw)\mathcal O(2^dnw)O(2dnw) time and O(d)\mathcal O(d)O(d) space, where www is the size of the largest transaction. 👎IMPRACTICAL!

The Apriori Algorithm

If X,Y∈2IX,Y\in 2^\mathcal IX,Y∈2I are two itemsets s.t. X⊆YX\subseteq YX⊆Y, the support σ(X)≥σ(Y)\sigma(X)\ge\sigma(Y)σ(X)≥σ(Y). We say that the support is anti-monotone.

The algorithm exploits the Apriori property by means of an iterative process that alternates frequent itemset generation, and candidate generation. Let CkC_kCk​ be the candidate itemsets of size kkk, let LkL_kLk​ be the frequent itemsets of size kkk. The Apriori algorithm starts from the intuition that, instead of generating all the itemsets, the candidates of size kkk should only contain frequent itemsets of size k−1k-1k−1.

Pseudo-code

Input: Data D\mathcal DD, items I\mathcal II, minimum support minsupminsupminsup.

  1. k←1k\gets 1k←1

  2. C1←IC_1\gets\mathcal IC1​←I

  3. while Ck≠∅C_k\neq\emptyCk​=∅ do

    // frequent itemset generation

    • Scan DB to find which itemsets in CkC_kCk​ are frequent, put them into LkL_kLk​

    // candidate generation

    • Use LkL_kLk​ to generate a collection of candidate itemsets Ck+1C_{k+1}Ck+1​ of size k+1k+1k+1.
    • k←k+1k\gets k+1k←k+1

Candidate generation. It constructs the candidate itemsets of size k+1k+1k+1 by combining frequent itemsets of size kkk. For simplicity, we assume that itemsets are ordered. Also we assume that itemsets in LkL_kLk​ are ordered. We can generate candidates of size k+1k+1k+1 by joining two itemsets of size kkk that share the first k−1k-1k−1 items. In a database terms, we are computing a self-join between the list of candidates of size kkk using the first k−1k-1k−1 columns as joining attributes.

Once a new candidate is generated, we can check whether all the ordered subsets are also frequent, i.e., they are in the set LkL_kLk​. This ensure the correct application of the Apriori principle. The generatiion of candidates Ck+1C_{k+1}Ck+1​ proceeds as follows

  1. Self-join LkL_kLk​: create set Ck+1C_{k+1}Ck+1​ by joining frequent kkk-itemsets that share the first k−1k-1k−1 items
  2. Pruning step: Remove a Ck+1C_{k+1}Ck+1​ candidate if a kkk-subset is not frequent.

Frequent itemset generation. Important step: counting the support for each of the candidates CkC_kCk​. Speed up by using hash map. Better solution: hash-tree.

Itemsets of size k=2k=2k=2. For a typical shop-basket data, the number of k=2k=2k=2 items is by far the largest among other kkk values. It’s important to have efficient, in-memory optimizations. There are 2 approaches:

  1. counting all pairs using a triangular matrix

    requires 4 bytes per pair

  2. keeping a table for triples [i,j,c][i,j,c][i,j,c], where ccc is the count of the pair of items (ii,ij)(i_i,i_j)(ii​,ij​).

    require 12 bytes per pair but only for those pair with positive count.

Factors Affecting the Complexity

  • Minimum support threshold
  • Dimensionality of the dataset
  • Size of Database
  • Average transaction width. It may increase max length of frequent itemsets and traversals of has h tree.

Association Rule Mining

It is a refinement of frequent itemsets, in which an itemset is frequent conditionally to another itemset. E.g. {a,b}⇒{c,d,e}\{a,b\}\Rarr\{c,d,e\}{a,b}⇒{c,d,e} means when items a,ba,ba,b occurs, also c,d,ec,d,ec,d,e occur.

Definition of association rule. It is an implication of the form X⇒YX\Rarr YX⇒Y as the number of items YYY appears in transactions that contain XXX, i.e., γ(X⇒Y)=σ(X∪Y)σ(X)\gamma(X\Rarr Y)=\frac{\sigma(X\cup Y)}{\sigma(X)}γ(X⇒Y)=σ(X)σ(X∪Y)​.

The association rule mining task finds all rules at least with support minsupminsupminsup and confidence mincon fmin con\ fmincon f. The algorithm is apriori + additional step to generate the rules. The algorithm proceeds:

  1. Frequent itemset generation. Generate all itemsets whose support is greater than minsupminsupminsup
  2. Rule generation. Generate rules with confidence at least mincon fmincon\ fmincon f for each frequent itemset, where a rule is a partitioning of a frequent itemset into left-hand-side and right-hand-side.

So the pending issue for new algorithm is how do we generate such rules.

Rule Generation

The naive way: enumerate all the LHS and RHS. The process takes for each frequent itemset SSS all subsets L⊂SL\subset SL⊂S and generates rules of the form S−L⇒LS-L\Rarr LS−L⇒L that satisfy minimum confidence.

Does confidence posses the desired apriori property? Not in the strict sense.

Luckily, the apriori property holds for rules generated from the same itemset.

If we move items from LHS to RHS as the support in the denominator of the confidence increases. As such, if a rule X⇒YX\Rarr YX⇒Y from the same item has confidence ≤minconf\le minconf≤minconf all rules in which the RHS is a superset of YYY also have low confidence and can be pruned.

So we generate a candidate rule by merging 2 rules that share the same prefix on RHS. This process is essentially the apriori algorithm on RHS.

FP-Tree and FP-Growth

A smarter and more intricate algorithm, that exploits a tree structure called FP-tree.

FP-tree construction. An FP-tree is a prefix tree that contains a compressed representation of the transaction database. Each transaction in the FP-tree is a overlapping path in the tree.

The first step before constructing the tree is sorting the itemsets to ensure the uniqueness of the prefixes.

  1. The construction of the FP-tree starts from an empty node. Each node has a label corresponding to an item and a counter, corresponding to the number of transactions in the paths containing the item.
  2. For each transaction follow the prefix-path and increase the counters on the way.
  3. If at some point we reach a leaf node we expand the path adding nodes with counter 1.
  4. Add a pointer between nodes that refer to the same item.

We add a header table corresponding to the first (from the left of the tree) correspondence of the item.

The final size of the tree depends on the redundancy in the transactions. In the best case, all transaction are the same and the FP-tree is a path. In worst case, all the transactions are different and the size of the tree is bigger than that of the data.

FP-Growth is an algorithm that takes the FP-tree as input and performs a divide-and-conquer strategy to enumerate all the frequent itemsets.

Pseudo-code

Itemsets mining with FP-Tree

Input: All frequent itemsets and their support

Output: The FP-tree, minimum support minsupminsupminsup

  1. Proceed in divide-and-conquer manner
  2. for each Items i∈Ii\in\mathcal Ii∈I do
    • Consider candidate itemsets CCC ending with iii
    • Recursion on CCC

The meta-algorithm works bottom-up. This means that for each possible last item, consider itemsets with last items one of items preceding it in the ordering.

The items are lexicographically ordered and the header-table contains the first occurrence of an item.

FP-Growth

Input: All frequent itemsets and their support

Output: The FP-tree, minimum support minsupminsupminsup

  1. Proceed in divide-and-conquer manner
  2. for each suffix XXX do
    • Construct a prefix-tree for XXX, compute support using header table and pointers
    • If XXX is frequent then
      • Recompute support
      • Prune infrequent items
      • Prune leaves and recur

However, the items counter of the items need to be updated as the global FP-tree contains the counters for all transactions, including those not ending with the considered suffix. The counters propagates bottom-up from the leaves to the root.

Once the counters are updated, if any of the labels have support less than minsupminsupminsup the node is pruned and the subtree of the node is attacked to the node’s father. After pruning, the suffix is removed from the tree and the computation proceeds recursively bottom-up.

Pros and Cons

👍

  • Efficient
  • Allows to compute support along with the frequent items.

👎

  • Efficiency depends on the compaction factor
  • If the tree is bushy, the number of sub-problems to solve is large

Ex : un aller simple 一张单程票 un aller-retour 一张往返票

形容词

prochain(e) 下一个的 既可以放在名词前，也可以放在名词后

  • prochain arrêt 下一站 prochain bus 下一班公交车

  • 和时间有关的放在名词后：

    samedi prochain 下周六 le mois prochain 下个月 l’année prochaine 明年

entry.title: Fair Division 7 Ex-ante and Ex-post Fairness
entry.content:
Objective: Explore randomized indivisible allocations (equivalent to fractional allocation) and their implications on fairness: the compatibility of Ex-ante and Ex-post fairness.

Activities: Study the paper Best of Both Worlds: Ex-Ante and Ex-Post Fairness in Resource Allocation.

What does Both worlds here means?

The indivisible allocation is randomized.

  • Before the allocation, each agent has a expected valuation for the bundle. Ex-ante WORLD I

  • After the allocation, each agent has its actual valuation for the bundle. Ex-post WORLD II

Iannis told me to ignore anything related to GROUP FAIRNESS.

Indivisible goods, additive valuations.

When RANDOMIZATION is allowed, it is possible to achieve envy-freeness.

When allocation is deterministic, achieving exact fairness is impossible but approximate notions such as EF1 can be guaranteed.

Goal: Achieve both simultaneously by randomized allocation that is fair ex-ante and approximately fair ex-post.

Algorithm that achieves ex-ante EF with ex-post EF1.

ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1 + economic efficiency? impossible. ❌

ex-ante EF + relaxed ex-post fairness + economic efficiency? feasible. ✔️

Introduction

If we allowed to randomize, then we can choose an agent uniformly at random and allocate the entire set of goods. This is trivially ex-ante envy-free since all agents receive the same distribution.

ex-ante 可以理解为预期的，先验的

ex-post 可以理解为实施确定分配后的，后验的

However, this allocation induces a large amount of envy ex-post because there are times when one agent receives everything while others receive nothing.

Some ex-post envy is unavoidable: 2 agents, 1 item.

EF1 always exists, which limits the ex-post envy, but still be unfair if some agents are systematically favored over others.

Question: Can we randomize over EF1 allocations s.t. the resulting randomized allocation is EF? aka ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1.

本论文提出的期望无嫉妒和后验嫉妒特一物分配，即

  • 分配前：所有智能体获得的价值的期望是 EF 的

  • 分配后：所有智能体真实获得价值是 EF1 的

This paper: Yes.

Basic Results

en-ante\ex-postProp1+EF11EF1EF1+POEF1+fPO
Prop✔️✔️❓❌ Thm. 3
EF✔️✔️ Thm. 2❓❌
GF✔️ Cor. 1❌ Thm. 3❌❌

Algorithm: Recursive Probabilistic Serial, which produces an ex-ante EF distribution over deterministic allocation that each satisfy EF1.

Impossibility of ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1 + ex-ante PO.

But with relaxation of ex-post fairness, awe are able to achieve ex-ante group fairness (GF) (aka EF + PO), in conjunction with Prop1 or EF11 (envy-freeness up to one good more-and-less)

EF1⇒EF11,EF1⇒PROP1EF1\Rarr EF_1^1,EF1\Rarr PROP1EF1⇒EF11​,EF1⇒PROP1.

Related Work

Omitted

Preliminaries

Agent N=[n]N=[n]N=[n], Indivisible item M=[m]M=[m]M=[m].

Fractional and Randomized Allocations

Fractional allocation: for every item jjj, we have ∑i∈NAi,j≤1\sum_{i\in N}A_{i,j}\le1∑i∈N​Ai,j​≤1.

Complete allocation: a fractional allocation AAA satisfying ∀j∈M,∑i∈NAi,j=1\forall j\in M,\sum_{i\in N}A_{i,j}=1∀j∈M,∑i∈N​Ai,j​=1. Otherwise call it partial allocation.

Integral allocation: a fractional allocation if Ai,j∈{0,1}∀i∈N,j∈MA_{i,j}\in\{0,1\}\forall i\in N,j\in MAi,j​∈{0,1}∀i∈N,j∈M.

Let X\mathcal XX be all fractional allocations w.r.t. N,MN,MN,M.

Randomized allocation

X\mathbf XX, a lottery over integral allocations.

X\mathbf XX is specified by a set of ℓ∈N\ell\in\mathbb Nℓ∈N ordered pairs {(pk,Ak)}k∈[ℓ]\{(p^k,A^k)\}_{k\in[\ell]}{(pk,Ak)}k∈[ℓ]​.

AkA^kAk is an integral allocation implemented with probability pk∈[0,1]p^k\in[0,1]pk∈[0,1].

Instead of starting from a method that guarantees ex-post EF1 and using it to achieve ex-ante EF, we do the opposite: Start from a fractional EF allocation and implement it using integral EF1 allocations.

Probabilistic serial is an algorithm that produces a fractional EF allocations.

  • serial eating protocol wherein all agents simultaneously start eating their respective favorite goods at the same constant speed.
  • Once a good is completely consumed by a subset of agents, each of those agents proceeds to eating her favorite available good at the same speed.
  • The algorithm terminates when all goods have been eaten, and fraction of each good consumed by an agent is allocated to her.

A very vivid algorithm

A useful property of this algorithm: it only uses the ordinal preferences of agents over goods, and computes an allocation that is ex-ante envy-free for any additive utilities consistent with the ordinal preferences. Thus, it’s SD-EF.

Use a variant of probabilistic serial, recursive probabilistic serial, which provides the desired fairness guarantees, i.e., ex-ante EF and ex-post EF1.

A Polynomial-Time Algorithm for Ex-ante EF + Ex-post EF1

Full randomized allocation constructed by Algorithm 1 require exponential time.

Approach to reducing the support size is to use the Carathéodory’s theorem from convex analysis: If a point x∈Rdx\in\mathbb R^dx∈Rd lies in the convex hull of a set PPP, then xxx can be expressed as a convex combination of at most d+1d+1d+1 vertices of PPP.

Any fractional allocation XXX is a point in an n×mn\times mn×m-dimensional space. By Carathéodory’s theorem, if it is a convex combination of integral allocations in the support {A1,⋯ ,Aℓ}\{A^1,\cdots,A^\ell\}{A1,⋯,Aℓ}, then it can also be written as a convex combination of at most nm+1nm+1nm+1 allocations from this set.

This establishes the existence of a convex combination with small support, it does not automatically provide an efficient algorithm for converting a convex combination with large support to one with small support.

In the modification of recursive probabilistic serial, we ensure that the support size remains mn+1mn+1mn+1 after every step of “branching out”.

Every step of branching out can increase the support size of mn+1mn+1mn+1 to (nm+1)⋅p(m,n)(nm+1)\cdot p(m,n)(nm+1)⋅p(m,n). Thus we need a way to reduce the support size from at most (mn+1)⋅p(m,n)(mn+1)\cdot p(m,n)(mn+1)⋅p(m,n) to at most nm+1nm+1nm+1.

🤔Proposition 3. There is a polynomial-time algorithm, that given a polytope P\mathcal PP with a strong separation oracle and a point y∈Py\in\mathcal Py∈P, returns a representation of yyy as a convex combination of dim⁡(P)+1\dim(\mathcal P)+1dim(P)+1 vertices of P\mathcal PP.

Notice that at the end of the first iteration t=1t=1t=1, the fractional partial allocation X1X^1X1 consists of a polynomial number of integral allocations in its support, i.e., X1=∑k=1ℓw1,kA1,kX^1=\sum_{k=1}^\ell w^{1,k}A^{1,k}X1=∑k=1ℓ​w1,kA1,k, where ℓ=p(m,n)\ell=p(m,n)ℓ=p(m,n) for some polynomial ppp. Consider the polytope P1\mathcal P^1P1 formed by the convex hull of the integral allocations A1,1,⋯ ,A1,ℓA^{1,1},\cdots,A^{1,\ell}A1,1,⋯,A1,ℓ as follows

\mathcal P^1=\{z:z=\sum_k\alpha_kA^{1,k}\text{ where }(\alpha_k\ge0\forall k\in[\ell])\and(\sum_k\alpha_k=1)\}

polytope 多胞体

  1. Convexity: A polytope is a convex set, meaning that for any two points inside the polytope, the line segment connecting them lies entirely within the polytope.
  2. Finite Set of Vertices: A polytope is defined by a finite set of vertices (or corners) in Euclidean space. These vertices are the extreme points of the polytope and determine its shape.
  3. Higher-Dimensional Analogues: Just as a polygon is a two-dimensional polytope and a polyhedron is a three-dimensional polytope, polytopes can exist in any finite number of dimensions. For example, a four-dimensional polytope is called a polytope, and a five-dimensional polytope is called a polychoron.
  4. Faces: The faces of a polytope are the lower-dimensional subsets of the polytope that are themselves polytopes. For example, in a three-dimensional polyhedron, the faces are the polygons that form its surface.
  5. Simplexes and Polygons: Simplexes are special types of polytopes that are defined as the convex hull of a set of affinely independent points. A simplex in two dimensions is a triangle, and in three dimensions, it is a tetrahedron. Polygons are also considered special cases of polytopes.

Observe that P1\mathcal P^1P1 admits a polynomial-time strong separation oracle. One can decide in polynomial time whether a given point y∈Rn×my\in\mathbb R^{n\times m}y∈Rn×m belongs to P1\mathcal P^1P1, or return a separating hyper-plane if it doesn’t. This implies that an (nm+1)(nm+1)(nm+1)-sized decomposition of X1X^1X1, as guaranteed by Carathéodory’s theorem can be computed in polynomial time.

Having computed an (nm+1)(nm+1)(nm+1)-sized decomposition of X1X^1X1, we obtain at most nm+1nm+1nm+1 sub-instances in each of which we re-run algorithm. Notice that this result in a probability distribution over (nm+1)⋅p(n,m)(nm+1)\cdot p(n,m)(nm+1)⋅p(n,m) deterministic allocations at the end of the second iteration. Re-invoke algorithmic version of Carathéodory’s theorem to obtain a decomposition over at most mn+1mn+1mn+1 of these integral allocations in polynomial time.

Observe that AAA violates PROP since v1(A1)=v1(g1)<12v1(g1∪g2)v_1(A_1)=v_1(g_1)\lt\frac{1}{2}v_1(g_1\cup g_2)v1​(A1​)=v1​(g1​)<21​v1​(g1​∪g2​).

Additionally, ex-ante EF and ex-ante GF imply ex-ante PROP, thus these are also incompatible with ex-post EF1 + PO.

Since ex-ante PO implies ex-post fPO, thus ex-ante (PROP + PO) and ex-ante (EF + PO) are incompatible with ex-post EF1.

Possibility: ex-ante GF + ex-post PROP1 + ex-post EF11

Omitted

Characterizing MNW

Seems related to GF, can be omitted.

The Case of Bads

“Bads” here means chores. aka all items are negative valued.

Let MMM be set of mmm bads. Fractional, integral and randomized allocations are defined analogously as in the case of goods.

However the agents have non-positive valuation functions. There are differences when defining fairness notions.

PROP1, aka proportionality up to one bad. An integral allocation AAA is PROP1 if for every agent iii, either vi(Ai)≥vi(M)/nv_i(A_i)\ge v_i(M)/nvi​(Ai​)≥vi​(M)/n or there exists a bad j∈Aij\in A_ij∈Ai​ s.t. vi(Ai╲{j})≥vi(M)/nv_i(A_i\diagdown\{j\})\ge v_i(M)/nvi​(Ai​╲{j})≥vi​(M)/n, where vi(M)v_i(M)vi​(M) is iii’s valuation for all bads.

EFk, aka envy-freeness up to kkk bads. An integral allocation AAA is EFk if for every pair of agent i,hi,hi,h, there ∃Si⊆Ai\exist S_i\subseteq A_i∃Si​⊆Ai​ with ∣Si∣≤k|S_i|\le k∣Si​∣≤k s.t. vi(Ai╲Si)≥vi(Ah)v_i(A_i\diagdown S_i)\ge v_i(A_h)vi​(Ai​╲Si​)≥vi​(Ah​).

EF11, aka envy-freeness up to one bad more-and-less. An integral allocation AAA is EF11 if for every pair of agent i,hi,hi,h s.t. Ai≠∅A_i\neq\emptyAi​=∅, we have vi(Ai╲{ji})≥vi(Ah∪{jh})v_i(A_i\diagdown\{j_i\})\ge v_i(A_h\cup\{j_h\})vi​(Ai​╲{ji​})≥vi​(Ah​∪{jh​}) for some bads ji∈Aij_i\in A_iji​∈Ai​ and jh∉Ahj_h\not\in A_hjh​∈Ah​.

Ex-ante EF + Ex-post EF1 for Bads

Recursive Probabilistic Serial and its polynomial-time variant only use ordinal preferences of agents over goods.

Problem here: Can we construct an ordinal preference over bads in which the bads are sorted in a non-increasing order of the agent’s valuation for them.

Both RPS and its polynomial-time variant are always ex-post EF2 for bads.

🤔Proposition 6. For additive valuation functions over bads, recursive probabilistic serial and its polynomial variant produce randomized allocation that are ex-ante EF and ex-post EF2.

eating procedure is EF because agents are forced to eat bads at the same rate and an agent is always eating a bad that she prefers the most among all bads not fully consumed.

Since each XtX^tXt is EF, a probability distribution over XtX^tXt in different branches is also envy-free. Hence, the expected fractional allocation induced in step ttt is EF for each ttt. Hence, ex-ante EF.

For ex-post EF2, let AAA be an integral allocation produced by RPS. By lemma 1 still holds for bads.

For t<⌈m/n⌉t\lt\lceil m/n\rceilt<⌈m/n⌉, if bi,tb_{i,t}bi,t​ denotes the bad allocated to agent iii in iteration ttt, then agent iii prefers bi,tb_{i,t}bi,t​ to all bads in Mt+1M^{t+1}Mt+1.

When t<⌊m/n⌋t\lt\lfloor m/n \rfloort<⌊m/n⌋, we know that another agent hhh must receive a bad in round t+1≤⌊m/n⌋t+1\le\lfloor m/n \rfloort+1≤⌊m/n⌋. Hence, for all agents i,h∈Ni,h\in Ni,h∈N and all t<⌊m/n⌋t\lt\lfloor m/n\rfloort<⌊m/n⌋, we have vi(bi,t)≥vi(bh,t+1)v_i(b_{i,t})\ge v_i(b_{h,t+1})vi​(bi,t​)≥vi​(bh,t+1​).

Summing over t<⌊m/n⌋t\lt\lfloor m/n\rfloort<⌊m/n⌋, we get

vi({bi,t:1≤t<⌊m/n⌋})≥vi({bh,t:2≤t≤⌊m/n⌋})≥vi(Ah)v_i(\lbrace b_{i,t}:1\le t\lt\lfloor m/n\rfloor\rbrace)\ge v_i(\lbrace b_{h,t}:2\le t\le\lfloor m/n\rfloor\rbrace)\ge v_i(A_h)vi​({bi,t​:1≤t<⌊m/n⌋})≥vi​({bh,t​:2≤t≤⌊m/n⌋})≥vi​(Ah​)

In the LHS, there are at most 2 bads missing from AiA_iAi​:

  • The bad allocated to agent iii in round ⌊m/n⌋\lfloor m/n\rfloor⌊m/n⌋
  • Tge bad which may be allocated tot agent iii in the final round ⌈m/n⌉\lceil m/n\rceil⌈m/n⌉

Q.E.D.

Naturally, the algorithm also produces ex-ante SD-EF + ex-post SD-EF2.

When mmm is a multiple of nnn, it turns out that the allocation is in fact ex-post EF1.

🤔Lemma 5. For additive valuation functions over bads, recursive probabilistic serial and its polynomial-time variant from Section 3.2 produce randomized allocations that are ex-ante envy-free (EF) and ex-post envy-free up to one bad (EF1) whenever the number of bads is divisible by the number of agents.

Proof by proposition 6.

If nnn divides mmm, we guarantee that there is only one bad missing from the LHS, which is that allocated to agent iii in round m/nm/nm/n.

Simple modification of RPS, simply add a number of “dummy bads” which all agent value at 000 s.t. the total number of bads becomes divisible by the number of nnn, then run RPS to compute ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1.

🎯🤔Theorem 6. For additive valuation over bads, there always exists a randomized allocation that is ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1 which can be computed in polynomial time.

What about fair division of mixed manna?

Each item can be either a good or a bad for each agent.

EF1 can be generalized to the mixed manna setting. It requires that if iii envies hhh, then the envy can be eliminated by either removing one item from agent hhh’s bundle (which must be a good for iii), or one item from agent iii’s bundle (which must be a bad for iii).

EF1 aka envy-freeness up to one item. An integral allocation AAA is EF1 if for every pair of agent i,hi,hi,h, either iii does not envy hhh, or there exists an item o∈Ai∪Aho\in A_i\cup A_ho∈Ai​∪Ah​ s.t. vi(Ai╲{o})≥vi(Ah╲{o})v_i(A_i\diagdown\{o\})\ge v_i(A_h\diagdown\{o\})vi​(Ai​╲{o})≥vi​(Ah​╲{o}).

The algorithm of this paper achieve the relaxation of EF1 in mixed manna setting, w-EF1.

w-EF1 aka weak envy-freeness up to one item. An integral allocation AAA is w-EF1 if for every pair i,hi,hi,h, either iii does not envy hhh, or there exists a good oh∈Aho_h\in A_hoh​∈Ah​ and/or a bad oi∈Aio_i\in A_ioi​∈Ai​ s.t. vi(Ai╲{oi})≥vi(Ah╲{oh})v_i(A_i\diagdown\{o_i\})\ge v_i(A_h\diagdown\{o_h\})vi​(Ai​╲{oi​})≥vi​(Ah​╲{oh​}).

🎯🤔Theorem 7. For additive valuation in the mixed manna setting, there always exists a randomized algorithm producing ex-ante EF + ex-post w-EF1, which can be computed in polynomial time.

Add dummy items to guarantee that mmm is a integer multiple of nnn, and remove them at the end.

When we run RPS on such instance, we can again apply the same argument as in the proof in proposition 6. That is equivalent to ex-post w-EF1 guarantee.

Of course, this results is also ex-ante SD-EF and ex-post SD-w-EF1 for mixed manna.

Ex-ante GF + Ex-post PROP1 + Ex-post EF11 for Bads

Omitted

Discussion

❓Open question:

  • ex-ante PROP + ex-post (EF1 + PO)
  • ex-ante EF + ex-post (EF1 + PO)

Difficulty: hard to analyze the methods of finding EF1 + PO allocations.

❓Open question:

  • Does there always exist an integral EF1 + PO allocation in which agent iii doesn’t envy agent jjj?
  • What about an integral EF1 + PO allocation in which agent iii does not envy any other agent?
  • Given a priority ordering over the agents, does there always exist an EF1 + PO allocation in which no agent envies an agent with lower priority?

Other possible work direction: EFX/MMS for ex-post fairness?

How about ex-ante and ex-post fairness guarantees in voting, matching and public decision-making?

我认为阅读部分最 SVÆRT 的题目，给五段话，每段话有一个句子不符合段落大意，需要划掉。因为生词太多了，根本读不懂！
